I don't normally post reviews, in fact this is the first.  I've played MMOs since UO, EQ, WOW, Shadowbane, LoA, etc etc etc and I really wanted to love this game.  There are some very good things, but mostly poor things currently in this game.  

The Devs did a GREAT job addressing the lag issue in this game very early on.  I still "rubber band" from time to time, but nothing like before where the game was basically unplayable. 

Crafting:  The map size is too small for the massive grind you are required to play with, if you want to gather/craft at all.  What do I mean?  In UO for example, I may have been required to farm  1,000,000 ingots to gain a level.  That's a grind right?  Sure no problem.  Because in UO there are hundreds of caves in different zones, and almost "endless" mountains I could get ore from.  In WT2, there might be 4 iron nodes in the gorge, and if you're lucky another 5 or so in the Cave after you spend an hour clearing it.   So you spend about 1.5 hours to get at best 9-10 iron nodes.  Which then turn into a few ingots.  The problem is, when you need tens of thousands, spending a few hours for 20 ingots isn't going to work.   The crafting system is designed so each level you are required to earn more exp, 100k one level, 113k another level, etc.  (Numbers are estimates are level 48 ish skill).  That isn't the real problem, as I said the real problem is the fact that the item/thing what have you to EARN the skill is VERY LIMITED.  So when you require 113,000 exp points, but you only earn 05 exp from making one item that took you 4 hours to grind the mats to make that one item, you get the idea. 

*IF YOU ARE A SOLO PLAYER YOU WILL NOT BE ABLE TO PROGRESS IN CRAFTING.* (Or if you try it, it would literally take you years, yes YEARS)  Again, not because the crafting is hard, but because of the LACK of resources in the world to gather to then craft.  


This doesn't just apply to blacksmith work either.  It's basically the same for every crafting skill.  As a tamer you need to tame wolves, hundreds of them.  Well when the world has a total of about 35 wolves, shared between you, other tamers, people leveling weapon skill, and people farming for leather, you get the idea.  

The grind itself isn't the problem; it really comes down to the lack of available resources to even try to work the grind.  

Desync - Ever press an instant cast spell and have to wait 3-5 seconds before it is applied to a target?  No? Me either until I played WT2.  I have gig fiber and run pretty smooth 40-60 MS ping.  The game is so based on a stun, that it's basically who gets stunned first? Okay then die.  There is no real way of healing, so everyone is stuck with 100 HP.  But the desync issue is, a player can be right in front of me, I press an instant cast stun, but because it takes 3-5 seconds for that stun to show up in game, the player I was attempting to stun is now 7 paces away from me.  So now you're stuck trying to press a stun 5-7 paces in FRONT of a player with your shield in hopes that that player will continue to run in the same direction to then have your stun applied.  Understand? Yeah... complete B/S.

PVP- I don't care about loot dropping in PVP.  It's a PVP sandbox, people should learn that before you buy it.  BUT what I do care about in PVP is balance. The player's guild name don't show up above there head either until you mouse over their names, which if they are a PK by the time you do all that, you're already stunned and basically dead. - Crafting was a very nice feature in the game. Though many hours of grinding were required, it felt very nice when you finally could hit that level and upgrade your gear. Now, unless you are the top crafter across all servers, you don't get rewarded for upgrading your crafting skills, because no one will buy your low-quality gear as everyone (including you) can just buy it, with much less grinding, in the cross-server Auction House.

- Fishing is notably (including by the devs) one of the worst features in the game and people have been botting a lot at that. What did the devs do? They made fishing mandatory for obtaining some of the end-game items. Quite hard to understand that decision.

- Heavy armor has been much superior to light armor, specially in late-game; it is so imbalanced, most people use heavy armor all the time, even for DPS roles. What do the devs do? They make light armor even worse by virtually taking away your main protection when you are mounted: your dodge chance is now divided by 4. While for heavy armor, you don't lose quite as much protection.

I am not to say they haven't made some good decisions as well, but these examples show they are not minding the consequences of their design decisions, making the overall game experience degrade over time. Sometimes it looks as though they are just throwing random stuff around.

So now they go ahead with more and more imbalanced gameplay, a faulty economy, close-to-irrelevant crafting and a 30% monthly reduction on an already small player base with the illusion that more content will make the game better. Some people think more content will be a game-changer, I don't. Maybe you'd better wait and see, but don't expect those basic problems to be corrected anytime soon, as devs seem oblivious to them, even when presented with strong evidence on some bad choices.

I don't think the game is beyond salvation, as it has some really interesting premises, but I don't see it getting good anytime in the next one or two years, unless the devs start thinking hard about their decisions and their consequences. And I wish they do, this game could become awesome.
